Assets.Asset_Name: Register address bus used to select internal registers (addr)
Assets.Functionality: Selects which internal register (e.g., IO_DIR, IO_OUT, INTMASK, INTFLAGS, PINCTRL, IO readback) is accessed within the module’s address window; used to generate cs_int and to decode rd/wr destinations.
Assets.Justification: Incorrect or malicious addressing can direct reads/writes to the wrong control/state register, corrupting configuration or state. Protecting the address used for register access preserves the integrity of configuration and data paths.

Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1262: The addr bus in the gpio_s module could be vulnerable if the granularity of address regions protected by register locks is insufficient, allowing unauthorized modifications to critical configuration registers.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1263: If physical access controls are inadequate, an attacker could manipulate the addr bus to access or modify internal registers, compromising the integrity of the gpio_s module's configuration.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1220: The addr bus may suffer from insufficient granularity of access control, potentially allowing unauthorized agents to access or modify security-sensitive registers within the gpio_s module.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-680: CAPEC-680 exploits CWE-1262 by manipulating the register address bus (addr) to redirect read/write operations to unintended internal registers, thereby compromising the integrity of the gpio_s module's configuration and state.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-401: CAPEC-401 exploits CWE-1263 by manipulating the addr bus to redirect write operations to unintended registers, compromising the integrity of the gpio_s module's configuration and state.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: CAPEC-74 leverages CWE-1263 by intercepting and altering the addr bus signals to access unauthorized registers, thereby undermining the integrity of the gpio_s module's control and data paths.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: CAPEC-180 exploits CWE-1220 by manipulating the address bus to redirect reads/writes to incorrect registers, compromising the integrity of the gpio_s module's configuration and state.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-680: [CWE-1262] CAPEC-680 exploits CWE-1262 by manipulating the register address bus (addr) to redirect read/write operations to unintended internal registers, thereby compromising the integrity of the gpio_s module's configuration and state.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-401: [CWE-1263] CAPEC-401 exploits CWE-1263 by manipulating the addr bus to redirect write operations to unintended registers, compromising the integrity of the gpio_s module's configuration and state.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: [CWE-1263] CAPEC-74 leverages CWE-1263 by intercepting and altering the addr bus signals to access unauthorized registers, thereby undermining the integrity of the gpio_s module's control and data paths.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: [CWE-1220] CAPEC-180 exploits CWE-1220 by manipulating the address bus to redirect reads/writes to incorrect registers, compromising the integrity of the gpio_s module's configuration and state.

Assets.Functionality: Defines per-bit pin direction; controls whether each io bit is driven by IO_OUT or left high-Z for input.
Assets.Justification: Tampering with direction can cause contention or unintended data sourcing/sinking. Direction settings are control state that must remain correct to ensure safe and correct operation.

Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1262: Improper access control for the IO_DIR register could allow untrusted software to alter pin directions, leading to contention or unintended data flows, compromising system integrity.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1221: Incorrect default settings for the IO_DIR register could lead to insecure states upon reset, allowing unauthorized changes to pin directions and compromising system integrity.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1220: Insufficient granularity in access control for the IO_DIR register could allow unauthorized agents to modify pin directions, leading to data contention or unintended operations.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-680: CAPEC-680 exploits CWE-1262 by manipulating the dynamic configuration parameters to alter the I/O direction settings in the IO_DIR register, compromising the integrity of the GPIO module by causing unintended data flow or contention.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: CAPEC-74 targets CWE-1262 by injecting unauthorized commands to modify the IO_DIR register, undermining the integrity of the GPIO module by altering pin directions and potentially leading to unsafe operational states.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-166: CAPEC-166, which involves leveraging configuration manipulation, can exploit CWE-1221 by altering the IO_DIR register settings in the gpio_s module, compromising the integrity of the I/O direction and potentially causing data contention or unintended data flow.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: By exploiting CWE-1220, CAPEC-180 could manipulate the IO_DIR register to alter GPIO pin directions, compromising the integrity of the control state and potentially causing data contention or unintended data flow.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: CAPEC-74 can exploit CWE-1220 by injecting unauthorized commands to modify the IO_DIR register, thereby undermining the integrity of the GPIO configuration and leading to incorrect or unsafe operation.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-680: [CWE-1262] CAPEC-680 exploits CWE-1262 by manipulating the dynamic configuration parameters to alter the I/O direction settings in the IO_DIR register, compromising the integrity of the GPIO module by causing unintended data flow or contention.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: [CWE-1262] CAPEC-74 targets CWE-1262 by injecting unauthorized commands to modify the IO_DIR register, undermining the integrity of the GPIO module by altering pin directions and potentially leading to unsafe operational states. [CWE-1220] CAPEC-74 can exploit CWE-1220 by injecting unauthorized commands to modify the IO_DIR register, thereby undermining the integrity of the GPIO configuration and leading to incorrect or unsafe operation.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-166: [CWE-1221] CAPEC-166, which involves leveraging configuration manipulation, can exploit CWE-1221 by altering the IO_DIR register settings in the gpio_s module, compromising the integrity of the I/O direction and potentially causing data contention or unintended data flow.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: [CWE-1220] By exploiting CWE-1220, CAPEC-180 could manipulate the IO_DIR register to alter GPIO pin directions, compromising the integrity of the control state and potentially causing data contention or unintended data flow.

Assets.Functionality: Latches per-pin interrupt status; software clears bits by writing ones to this register; drives int via OR-reduction.
Assets.Justification: Unauthorized setting/clearing can fabricate or hide events, disrupting system operation and diagnostics. Integrity of the flags is required to accurately reflect edge events and control int.

Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1262: Improper access control for the INTFLAGS register could allow unauthorized software to manipulate interrupt flags, compromising the integrity of event detection.
Justification of Related CWE-IDs.CWE-1220: Insufficient granularity of access control could allow unauthorized agents to modify the INTFLAGS register, leading to fabricated or hidden interrupt events.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-680: CAPEC-680 can exploit CWE-1262 by manipulating the dynamic configuration parameters to unauthorizedly alter the INTFLAGS register, compromising its integrity by fabricating or hiding interrupt events.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: CAPEC-74 can exploit CWE-1262 by injecting malicious input through the addr and bus_in signals to improperly set or clear bits in the INTFLAGS register, undermining its integrity and disrupting accurate event reporting.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: By exploiting CWE-1220, CAPEC-180 can manipulate the dynamic configuration parameters of the gpio_s module to unauthorizedly alter the INTFLAGS register, compromising its integrity by fabricating or hiding interrupt events.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: CAPEC-74 leverages CWE-1220 by injecting malicious input through the gpio_s module's address and data buses to unauthorizedly set or clear bits in the INTFLAGS register, thus disrupting the integrity of interrupt status reporting.

Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-680: [CWE-1262] CAPEC-680 can exploit CWE-1262 by manipulating the dynamic configuration parameters of the gpio_s module to unauthorizedly alter the INTFLAGS register, compromising its integrity by fabricating or hiding interrupt events. [CWE-1262] CAPEC-680 can exploit CWE-1262 by manipulating the dynamic configuration parameters to unauthorizedly alter the INTFLAGS register, compromising its integrity by fabricating or hiding interrupt events.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-74: [CWE-1262] CAPEC-74 targets CWE-1262 by injecting malicious input through the addr and bus_in signals to improperly set or clear bits in the INTFLAGS register, undermining the integrity of interrupt status reporting. [CWE-1220] CAPEC-74 leverages CWE-1220 by injecting malicious input through the gpio_s module's address and data buses to unauthorizedly set or clear bits in the INTFLAGS register, thus disrupting the integrity of interrupt status reporting. [CWE-1262] CAPEC-74 can exploit CWE-1262 by injecting malicious input through the addr and bus_in signals to improperly set or clear bits in the INTFLAGS register, undermining its integrity and disrupting accurate event reporting.
Justification of Related CAPEC-IDs.CAPEC-180: [CWE-1220] By exploiting CWE-1220, CAPEC-180 can manipulate the dynamic configuration parameters of the gpio_s module to unauthorizedly alter the INTFLAGS register, compromising its integrity by fabricating or hiding interrupt events.
